title: Brigitte Bardot: From Screen Icon to Animal Rights Advocate
summary: Brigitte Bardot, a French actress born in 1934, rose to international fame in the 1950s with her role in 'And God Created Woman,' directed by her husband Roger Vadim. This film, part of the French New Wave, showcased her sensual and carefree persona, redefining femininity and making her a sensation at Cannes. Throughout the late 1950s and 1960s, she starred in critically acclaimed films like 'The Truth,' 'Contempt,' and 'Viva Maria!,' demonstrating her range from dramatic to comedic roles. Bardot's style, including her tousled hair and bold eyeliner, influenced global fashion trends. In 1973, at age 39, she retired from acting to focus on animal rights, founding the Brigitte Bardot Foundation. She campaigned against seal hunting and animal testing, shifting from a cinematic icon to a dedicated activist. Bardot settled in Saint-Tropez, living a quieter life until her death at 91, leaving a legacy of glamour, controversy, and conviction.

background_read: Brigitte Bardot was a pivotal figure in 20th-century cinema and activism. Born in Paris in 1934, she initially trained as a ballerina before transitioning to acting. Her marriage to director Roger Vadim led to her breakthrough in 'And God Created Woman,' a film that challenged traditional views of female sexuality. As part of the French New Wave, Bardot's roles in films like 'Contempt' by Jean-Luc Godard showcased her artistic depth. Beyond acting, she became a fashion icon and later a passionate advocate for animal rights, founding her own foundation. This article explores her journey from a glamorous screen star to a committed activist, highlighting key films and her impact on both pop culture and social causes.
